document_data.mainbody:
ire-eggs were a type of egg-based dish commonly found being served by higher quality inns within cites and towns.
This dish consisted of hard-boiled eggs &mdash usually sourced from a hen, but sometimes from a duck &mdash that had been cut in half to release their yolks. These yolks were then blended with either honey or mustard and then spooned back into the cut half of the egg.
